transcription.text: We're about to kick out the Ethereum 1/Ethereum 2 transition.
I think that Danny is the right person who will introduce you the topic.
Thank you.
Yeah.
I'm Danny. I work at the Ethereum Foundation on a lot of A2 stuff.
The question of what the existing Ethereum chain does and is in relationship to Ethereum
2.0 has been kind of an open question over the past year as the Ethereum 2.0 protocol
has emerged and people have begun to work on it.
For a while, it was maybe it would be rolled in as a smart contract within One's Shard
that was also floated. Maybe it just exists in parallel forever and we let it die.
Both of those, one of those seemed kind of complex and the challenges were not so clear
how to solve them and the other, it just letting it exist forever.
It kind of didn't feel like the humanist approach as Casey likes to put it.
It didn't, all of these humans in this room work on the Ethereum protocol.
So, it's been a priority to figure out a better way to slot ETH 1 into ETH 2.
There's a lot of conversations this week around execution, execution environments.
It turns out this very highly abstracted execution notion of execution might allow us to more
easily slot ETH 1 into ETH 2 as its own execution environment.
But there's a lot of things to figure out what that actually looks like.
And then more importantly, even if you do that, we now have this, we essentially have
all these developer interfaces on how we interact with the existing Ethereum chain.
And one of the big upcoming challenges is how do we take all of these developer interfaces
and once we've made this, or prior to making this migration, how do we kind of rework the
internals of these, expose very similar, if not the same, interfaces such that the developer
experience is fluid and continuous through that migration.
Definitely this is kind of the lay of the land of the problems.
It's the technical problem of how ETH 1 becomes an EE if during that transition what we,
what things we might choose to change.
There's been talks about changing the Mercle tree structure.
How certain things like block difficulty and things like that are translated, some of
these old op codes and things might change.
Do you open up the sharded universe to this EE and expose new things to Ethereum 1 within
Ethereum 2, a number of other challenges like that.
So it's kind of the technical challenges of that migration and the developer layer challenges
of masking the complexity and kind of like shifting the entire community over.
Is that the kind of stuff that we wanted to talk about today?
Okay cool.

One other component of this migration that I wanted to mention is that EEs, an execution

What can regular users expect from the transition?
How would they be impacted in any sense?
In the short term not, unless you personally choose to take your 32 ETH or stick it into

If you do, then you'll be able to start experiencing the wonderful world of ETH 2 early.
If you do not, then nothing will happen.

very close to no disruption at all.
The two worst things that might happen, one is that the chain might have to halt for some
period of time to make the transition go smoothly to allow the more cold routes to be
re-computed according to some more efficient restructure and so on.
The second thing is, as I mentioned in the previous panel, gas costs for opcodes that
touch state are going to have to be increased massively both for you through compatibility

Some applications might have to change the way that they're implemented and are going

In that, and I mentioned it explicitly at the beginning, the challenge, and a lot of

So early, mid-next-year, I think, forming some sort of group of people that do work on

I had a question on the shift to proof of stake.
Are there any specific points in time or really events that are important for this
transition in terms of maintaining the security of the network?
If it becomes more secure at some point, then what the parameters are?
So the parameters that probably matter are the events that you need to care about.
One is the time that the deposit contract gets published, and so if you're a validator,
you will be able to kind of pre-join.
The other is the time when the chain launches.
And basically, if you're a validator, you should be sure that you have a client running
at that point.
And when the chain launches, you'll have a proof of stake chain running.
The next major milestone after that would be the phase one switch.
And the phase one switch is important because that's the time when shard chains will turn
on.
And so that's the time when, especially if you have a lot of ETH3, your computational
requirements will increase, because your computational requirements will basically be
proportional to the amount of ETH3 you have, the more ETH3 you have, the more validators
want to have, and so the more shard blocks you will be called to make a crosslink on.
And then after that, there will continue to be forks, but kind of the general way the
chain works will continue to be fairly similar.
And then after that, of course, the ETH3 merge the details of which haven't been fully
figured out yet.
So in that roadmap, we still don't have a way to exit from being a validator.
